text: - Is that a monkey?
- What the hell is that?

BRIAN LOWRY: After dutiful
remakes in 1976 and 2005,

"King Kong" gets a more
ambitious makeover with "Kong--
Skull Island."
- What the hell is this place?

BRIAN LOWRY: Yet this attempt
to launch a new franchise

of creature features
suffers from a weak
script and uninspired design--

- This planet
doesn't belong to us.
BRIAN LOWRY: --making "Kong--

Numbskull Island" a
slightly more apt title.
- Monsters exist.

BRIAN LOWRY: This
new Kong gets points

for its economical
structure, since nearly

all the action takes place
on his remote island.

The story also cleverly
sets the action in 1973,

near the end of the Vietnam
War, as the mysterious Monarch

Group enlists a
military escort to help
explore this strange world.

What emerges, though,
is an odd mashup--

part monster movie,
part "Apocalypse Now."
And while there's a good cast--

including Tom Hiddleston, Brie
Larson, and Samuel L. Jackson--

based on the material, everyone
appears to be slumming.

Your friend there
can put that down.

Kong also looks different
than past versions,
much bigger and less apelike.

Similarly, the other
fantastic beasts

are less prehistoric,
more Pacific Rim, which
makes them feel pretty generic.

Mostly, this feels like the
opening phase in a larger
corporate enterprise.

And while its leading
man might be gigantic,

"Kong" doesn't set
the bar very high.
Brian Lowry, CNN.
